title: Ricky Riccitelli
text:
John Ricky Riccitelli (; born 3 February 1995) is a New Zealand professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer who plays as a <a href="Hooker%20%28rugby%20union%29">hooker</a> for New Zealand franchise <a href="Blues%20%28Super%20Rugby%29">Blues</a>. In his youth career, he was selected to play in the 2015 <a href="World%20Rugby%20Under%2020%20Championship">World Rugby Under 20 Championship</a>s for <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a> and took part in <a href="Francis%20Douglas%20Memorial%20College">Francis Douglas Memorial College</a> first XV.
Riccitelli represents the <a href="Taranaki%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Taranaki</a> provincial team and made his <a href="Professional%20sport">professional</a> debut for the union in 2017 at the age of 22. He spent a season at the <a href="Hawke%27s%20Bay%20Rugby%20Union">Hawke's Bay</a> side, before earning a short-term contract in the Hurricanes <a href="2016%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2016 Super Rugby</a> squad. He has defended the <a href="Ranfurly%20Shield">Ranfurly Shield</a> with Hawke's Bay in 2014 and Taranaki in 2017, won a championship with the Hurricanes in 2016 and was named Player of the Year at the <a href="Taranaki%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">TRFU</a> Amber and Black awards. He has scored 11 career <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">tries</a> in all competitions.
Early life.
John Ricky Riccitelli was born on 3 February 1995 in <a href="Durban">Durban</a>, the son of Gail Luiz and John Riccitelli. Riccitelli and his parents migrated to <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> when he was four-years-old after his mother got a job in the country. Settling in <a href="Oakura">Oakura</a>, he grew up in <a href="New%20Plymouth">New Plymouth</a> where he attended <a href="Francis%20Douglas%20Memorial%20College">Francis Douglas Memorial College</a>. While at secondary school, Riccitelli excelled in sports like <a href="Cricket%20%28sport%29">cricket</a> and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> and was granted his school's sportsman of the year award in 2012. In cricket, he appeared in <a href="Taranaki%20cricket%20team">Taranaki</a> junior grade sides, his school's first XI for four years since 2009 as well as the <a href="Central%20Districts">Central Districts</a> under-19 squad.
He represented <a href="Taranaki%20Region">Taranaki</a> in rugby at under-14 through under-18 levels and gained <a href="Hurricanes%20%28rugby%20union%29">Hurricanes</a> under-16 tournament team selection in 2012. While studying at <a href="Otago%20University">Otago University</a> for three years, Riccitelli played for the Southern club in <a href="Dunedin">Dunedin</a> and also captained the Otago under-19s. In 2015, Riccitelli departed for the <a href="2015%20World%20Rugby%20Under%2020%20Championship">Under 20 World Championship</a> in <a href="Italy">Italy</a>, regularly spending time doing skill sessions with former <a href="Otago%20Highlanders">Highlanders</a> assistant coach <a href="Jon%20Preston">Jon Preston</a>. Having also turned out for <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand U20's</a> in the <a href="2015%20Oceania%20Under%2020%20Rugby%20Championship">Oceania Junior Championship</a> earlier in the year, Riccitelli went on to feature in seven out of eight of the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Baby Blacks'</a> games, (including their historic win over <a href="England%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> in the <a href="2015%20World%20Rugby%20Under%2020%20Championship">U20 WC</a> final), starting at <a href="Rugby_union_positions%23Prop">loosehead prop</a>.
Professional career.
2015–17.
Although there was interest from other provincial unions for Riccitelli, he ended up signing a two-year deal with <a href="Hawke%27s%20Bay%20Rugby%20Union">Hawke's Bay</a> under coach Craig Philpott in May 2015. Philpott was impressed with his performance after noticing him at the New Zealand under-20 trial camps. He made his debut for the province in 2015, playing the two out of the three pre-season <a href="Ranfurly%20Shield">Ranfurly Shield</a> matches against <a href="Horowhenua-Kapiti%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Horowhenua-Kapiti</a> and <a href="Mid%20Canterbury%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Mid Canterbury</a>. He made a further six appearances during the <a href="2015%20ITM%20Cup">2015 ITM Cup</a> season.
Riccitelli then joined the <a href="Hurricanes%20%28rugby%20union%29">Hurricanes</a> after being called up into the squad to replace the injured <a href="Dane%20Coles">Dane Coles</a>. He made his <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> debut in the squads 23-man team to play the <a href="Brumbies">Brumbies</a> in their season opener. He then had his short-term injury cover contract with the Hurricanes extended after his work ethic impressed the coaching staff. After the Hurricanes' success throughout the season, Riccitelli appeared in all three finals, including their <a href="2016%20Super%20Rugby%20Final">grand final</a> win over the <a href="Lions%20%28Super%20Rugby%29">Lions</a>, impressing the Hurricanes' coaches with his accurate lineout throwing and strong ball-carrying.
In 2016 also saw Riccitelli feature in a disappointing Hawke's Bay team that finished in last place. He continued to make progress though as a starting loosehead prop during their Mitre 10 Cup campaign. Riccitelli, returned to his primary and preferred role of hooker when the side hosted <a href="Bay%20of%20Plenty%20Rugby%20Union">Bay of Plenty</a>, which was their final outing of the season at Napier's <a href="McLean%20Park">McLean Park</a>. He extended his club's appearances to eighteen after he played in all ten of Hawke's Bay's matches, making it a season's personal best.
Riccitelli returned to his home province of Taranaki. Having already secured <a href="Jordie%20Barrett">Jordie Barrett</a>, Taranaki had lured Riccitelli for the 2017 and 2018 Mitre 10 Cup season's, him to signing a two-year deal. With hooker <a href="Rhys%20Marshall">Rhys Marshall</a> taking up an offer to play for <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a> in <a href="Ireland">Ireland</a> at the end of the previous season, coach <a href="Colin%20Cooper%20%28rugby%29">Colin Cooper</a> said Riccitelli had a chance to claim the vacant hooker position.
Riccitelli became a regular starter for the Hurricanes in the <a href="2017%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2017 Super Rugby season</a> after another injury to Hurricanes' captain and first-choice <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">All Blacks</a> hooker Dane Coles. He was preferred over <a href="Leni%20Apisai">Leni Apisai</a> for the role. Riccitelli was eventually called up as injury cover for the All Blacks' <a href="2017%20Rugby%20Championship">2017 Rugby Championship</a>, with Coles out of the first round and <a href="Liam%20Coltman">Liam Coltman</a> out for the season. Riccitelli did not play in the competition and was released back to Taranaki after Coles recovered from his second concussion of the 2017 season.
2018–present.
Despite newly-capped All Black <a href="Asafo%20Aumua">Asafo Aumua</a> being signed to the Hurricanes for the <a href="2018%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2018 Super Rugby season</a>, Riccitelli held on to his place as a regular starter for the Hurricanes in the first three rounds of the competition. He started in all thirteen matches for the Hurricanes, played the third-most minutes for the side and made the second-most tackles before earning his second call-up for the New Zealand national team. Riccitelli was brought in as backup for <a href="Nathan%20Harris%20%28rugby%20union%29">Nathan Harris</a> ahead of the third test against <a href="France%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">France</a> in <a href="Dunedin%2C%20New%20Zealand">Dunedin</a>.
Riccitelli returned for his second <a href="Mitre%2010%20Cup">Mitre 10 Cup</a> season with Taranaki after being included in their 47-man squad to defend the <a href="Ranfurly%20Shield">Ranfurly Shield</a>. He was named player of the year for the province after appearing in nine out of twelve matches during the <a href="2018%20Mitre%2010%20Cup">2018 campaign</a>. Riccitelli later gained selection honours with <a href="Robbie%20Deans">Robbie Deans</a>' <a href="World%20XV">World XV</a> against <a href="Japan%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Japan</a> in <a href="Osaka">Osaka</a> after being named among the ten replacements. The side also featured current New Zealand internationals <a href="Nehe%20Milner-Skudder">Nehe Milner-Skudder</a> and <a href="Jackson%20Hemopo">Jackson Hemopo</a>.
Riccitelli rejoined the Hurricanes squad for their upcoming season after head coach <a href="John%20Plumtree">John Plumtree</a> included him in the <a href="2019%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2019 Super Rugby</a> side announcement in October 2018. He made his first appearance of 2019 against the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Waratahs">Waratahs</a> at <a href="Brookvale%20Oval">Brookvale Oval</a> on 16 February. Riccitelli made his 50th appearance for the Hurricanes franchise alongside <a href="Vaea%20Fifita">Vaea Fifita</a> after being named to start the match at <a href="Westpac%20Stadium">Westpac Stadium</a> against the <a href="Crusaders%20%28rugby%20union%29">Crusaders</a>.
